name: eversion
description: The Princess of the Flower Kingdom has vanished! She was taken by the Ghulibas of the north, and it is up to brave Zee Tee to rescue her. On his quest, he - and you - will discover the hidden lands behind the peaceful kingdom, and come face to face with secrets that will set you on edge!
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows XP or later Processor: Single core 1GHz+ Memory: 64MB or more Graphics: 640 x 480 resolution or higher DirectX®: N/A Hard Drive: 20 MB Sound: Required

reviews.review_text: A pretty Mario like game about a flower named Zee Tee who’s on an adventure to save a princes. What is this? “Press ‘X’ to evert,” okay.  X  Oh, well um- I didn’t expect that. Well anyway, like I was saying; it is a Mario style game where you go right, collect gems, jump on goomba like enemies and get to the end of the levels. It’ main gimmick is “everting”, at certain points in the levels you press “x”-  X  -and the world changes from the happy ... fun ... world to a darker more ... depressing and ... Lovecraftian ... world, I guess. There are 8 world to evert though.  X  Oh who cares, were all just gonna die. That all there is, suffering and death! What? You want me to talk about the game? It’s short! It’s has like 8 levels and then it ends! Like everyone else and everything else it goes away leaving me alone to die in this cold desolate world!  X  Whhaaaa haaaa haaaa, eeehhhaaaaa hhhaaaa haaaa, abggg ebggl, eeahhh haaa haaa.  X  ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ...  X  He, hehehe, hehe haha, hahaha hehee. Ha ha ha, ha ha hehe he hehe ha he ha he.  X  Mwahh haaa haaa haa haa! The hands will rise from the earth and when the 240 gems come together the dark King and Queen will come together. Beelzebub, Ahriman, Shaggoth, Yog Sothoth, arise, arise and slater the innocent! Ahh, haa haa haa haa!

{SPOILERS AHEAD}  I went into this expecting a super cute platformer game, and my god, never judge any more books by the cover. About half way into the game, it started going to hell, and I mean litterally, there were black arms with red clawed hands shooting up out of the water!! Backgrounds get gnarled and twisted, death screens give you occaisonal messages such as 'Ready! To die', 'Stop', 'Give up', and 'Mother', it truley turns into something you'd see in an internet creepypasta.  It's very short, I was able to complete it in under an hour, but very entertaining. I'm not sure if I would call it worth $4.99, so maybe wait for a sale to get this odd little gem of a game.   Moral of this story, book covers can troll you.  7/10

1 minute in the game: Awww 3 Minute in the game: what? 7 minute in the game: W-whats going on? 10 minute in game: ummmm.......? 15 minute in the game: This game is creepy as ♥♥♥♥. 20 minute in the game crying from how it was: I must finish this.  11/10 its a trap.

An absolutely outstanding game, Eversion is a good enough platformer, but has some rather neat other 'layers' to it, with each layer having it's own rules. It's a tad short, took me about two hours to beat everything and get the 'true' ending, but they were two wonderful hours. Seriously, get this, it's great.

Looks can be decieving, to some it will be less horror and more so a surprising puzzle ish kind of platformer. The only thing that needs to be known about this title is that it includes quotes from various H.P. Lovecraft stories, idealy at the mountains of madness and that is reason enough for me to recommend this as a nice, short, contending horror title  Edit: after looking at the global achievements, I saw that most people who playe the game, never even got down into the nitty gritty portion of it that made it what it was, and that makes me kinda upset ya know? I mean it's not the creators fault that this is what actually is the lowest selling Lovecraft inspired game I mean LOOK at the main page, it says nothing of the horrors to come other than a glimmer! I want this to be a best selling it's great that more it's review status recently went from positive to very but I just don't feel that's enough for it. But if you're someone who can't get enough lovecraftian style anything, I highly reccomend this glistening gemstone of evil to you for the measily price of $4.99
So cute little game with adorable musics, I really enjoyed playing it. Also, achievements are easy to get. I highly recommend this game! :)

A very short platformer (took me 4 hours to beat it and get all of the achievements) that starts off innocent enough, but the later levels can be a little tough. It controls well, the music is good, and it looks great.  It's worth a good dollar, but I wouldn't go much higher than that due to it's length.
Fun and frustrating. I screamed at my monitor quite a few times but it was worth it.

It's hard to review such a game without spoiling, all i can say is if you liked the freeware version, you WILL enjoy the updated version here, and enjoy hunting around for the small bit of things added in this versions
Fun for the whole family to play at midnight!
Extremely short game, but an irreplaceable experience, with some serious 'what the... ' moments.  If you can buy this for 1-2$, it is definitely worth it.
A basic platformer, based on Super Mario Bros, which the levels are getting more morbid, dark and creepy as you progress.

No beating around the bush. This is a game that, in its entirely, is an exploration of that weird moment half-way through the first level of Monster Party for NES where things get weird. Wrapped around that concept is an okay, and extremely basic, platformer. The graphics are passable. The music ranges from pretty good   (don't think I didn't notice you ... 'being inspired by' the title and first level themes from Cocoron, though~)   to (fittingly) awful. The story is basically nonexistent.  I can recommend it on four points;  1. The concept is interesting and there's nothing really  bad  about the game.  2. It's extremely cheap.  3. The true ending   was actually really heartwarming, somehow.    4. The jab at Braid in one of the achievements.

This is a quick play, but it's a fun platformer. It takes the usual cutesy platformer and adds a really creepy edge to it. I'd recommend it at the next sale to anyone who likes a good platformer with a twist and multiple endings. The graphics are simple and could use a slight boost, but it works. The controls occasionally gave me trouble, but not often enough to be too frustrating. The achievements weren't too difficult, but offered a fun challenge and a bit of replayability. Also it has trading cards. So there's that.
Short, sweet, and simply fun. An endearing platformer that's very unique. Very optimistic, showing us that nothing can stop true love.
Not quite what you think it is. Very worthwhile to figure out all the endings. Platforming is servicable. Good if you're looking for something... different.

Ah, yes, Eversion; a   seemingly   innocent little 8-bit romp   which quickly turns out to be a brilliantly set-up ruse   with 8 colorful little levels and 240 gems to collect. You also gotta save da princess   who turns out to be a psychotic ♥♥♥♥♥ who wants you to turn into her little bug♥♥♥♥ insane pet    It's a great game. Get it!   heh. heh heh heh......      Really, though; it's one of the most creepy retro-style things you'll ever play. It starts out easy and harmless, then gradually becomes an unsettling horror puzzle platformer that isn't for ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. I personally wasn't scared of it at all (though the hand at the end of the bonus level scared the ♥♥♥♥ out of me since it comes completely out of nowhere with almost no hint despite you ending the stage on layer 1). If you can handle some spookz, then I'd say get it. It's a fascinating lil' thing, if nothing else.      in other words: 3spooky5me

A must-play, solely for the plot twists. Consequently, there is no effective way to advertise this game without spoiling it, but this is undoubtedly a game worth the time and money.  Overall, a delightful game for all ages!  Play alone in the dark for best results.

this game used to be quite popular so if you haven't played it before let me boil it down for you:  Firstly, don't watch anything about this game on the first hand, and note that there does exist a freeware version of this game. If you are iffy on this game, play the freeware version of the game first.  This is just an HD remake of the game. You will either like it or hate it. I don't think there's much inbetween.  The entire game is based off of one gimmick, and if you like the gimmick you'll like the game, but if you hate it it'll just be a subpar platformer.

Eversion is a platformer that takes cues from some older, more recognised platformers — like Mario. It looks like a cute little retro game, where you play a small flower-like creature out to rescue a princess. You collect gems, stomp enemies, and reach the flag. However, in reality, it’s ”cute” and familiar only to deceive the player.  One unique feature — and the main idea of this game — is “eversion”. In specific, small, invisible “hotspots” in the game (that you can reach) you can switch to another sort-of parallel reality, where some rules might be different. For example, clouds can be walked on in some realities, and in others, shrubs become trees that block your path.  The game’s called “Eversion” for a reason: as you progress through the game, it starts “turning inside out”, revealing the hell inside this beautiful, peaceful world. You start off in a cute dreamy land, collecting gems and passing by (or stomping) happy, innocent “enemies” that skip around. Soon enough, these enemies turn worse and your surroundings change. At some point, the game even starts lying to the player and occasionally tries to discourage the player from continuing, while at the same time breaking the fourth wall.  Eversion is rather short (less than an hour, possibly more to max it out), but it’s a great experience that anyone should play. It challenges game design standards and does a lot of things completely different compared to standard games, even indie ones.
A nice cute and fun game to buy for your kids
Love the thematics in this game, if you want to make it extra difficult and frustrating play it with a keyboard instead of a controller.
Just play it. Don't watch the trailer or read anything, or you will spoil it.
Iz great game
Hey everyone and this is my review about the game!  It is a Platform mini-puzzle game!   Interface/Menu/Settings
Beginning thoughts: 'Meh, this is somewhat amusing I guess.'  Final thoughts: 'Can't judge a book by it's cover. Someone needs some therapy. I know I do.'

'The horror!'  A cheap little platformer, this might be one of the smallest games on Steam. I imagine anyone buying it just wanted it because it was cheap and looked cute.   How wrong you are.   Story Something about the princess being taken is written on the store page. You won't really see much story once in the game, except for the ending.   Presentation Cute graphics here, they are what drew me in to purchasing this game. Little did I know that would soon change to a nightmarish landscape rather quickly. While they are rather basic and obviously inspired by classic games, they still look nice.  The isn't a lot of music in the game, but it fits the setting. Simple sound effects that do the job as well. Not really much to say about them.   Controls As the controls are rather simple, they work well on keyboard, but gamepads also have support if you prefer those. Movement, jumping, the Eversion ability (which shall be detailed below) and a pause button. You could play this with a NES clone controller if you own one.   Gameplay Run, jump, bounce off enemy heads, collect the gems and reach the end of the level. Sounds like any NES era platformer game, right? Well, since the game opens up with a Lovecraft quote, there is obviously going to be something creepy lurking in the shadows. And that is where the Eversion ability comes in. In each level, there are locations where the walls between realities are weak. If you can find them, you can shift to another reality, often darker than the one you were already in. This will have an effect on both the landscape and enemies. That bush will wither and die, only to be replaced by deadly vines. Enemies may lose the will to live, just standing there for you to end its life, or it may get faster and more dangerous. Switching realities is needed to get all the gems through the levels, and sometimes even to progress forward through what would otherwise block movement.   Lifespan This game is short. Including the final level which requires you to find all the gems, you are unlikely to spend more than an hour or two doing the main game, including the different endings. Once you have seen the true ending, you do unlock a time attack mode with leader boards, which can add to the time spent on the game. There is also a level editor available, though I haven't played around with any of the community content myself.   While not a bad game, the short game length alone is a good enough reason to only get on sale or with a Steam discount coupon.  6 / 10

I'd like to do a Completionist-style review for this game. Because his reviews are awesome.  Foreword, Eversion is a quick Mario-style platformer and also a Lovecraftian game meaning the game starts out cute and bright, but as you progress through, it gets darker and darker. It also has achievements and trading card content to go with it! Eversion started out as a free online game, then implemented to Steam with HD graphics and new updated features.  THE STORY Zee Tee, the cute protagonist of the game, looking like an orange star-shaped creature with legs, has to go out in the land and save the princess Nehema. Zee Tee is able to 'Everse' to different layers of the world. Which get darker and scarier as he gets lower and lower in the layers. The other entities get dangerous and horrid as he gets lower. The game has three different endings based on what you do in the last few levels.  THE PRESENTATION The game begins in the top layer, where everything is bright, colorful, and cute, just like the first few levels of a Mario game! There are flowers and blue skies. Once you cross to the first eversion layer, which is right below the top one (Not the one you started at), the first layer shows a lower saturation of visuals, and you can see several things have slowly deteriorated. In fact, if you get down into lower eversion layers, they deteriorate even more and the other creatures get more monstrous. Also blood. It's a rather disturbing game. That's why you should acknowledge the fine print at the start of the game: 'not intended for children or those of a nervous disposition'.  THE GAMEPLAY The game has seven levels before the main ending. Each level is short and quick. Use the arrow keys to control your character, and press the Space bar to locate Eversion portals and flip through layers when at one. However in deeper layers, you won't be able to locate them, but you'll know when you're at them when the background partially changes. There are also gems in each level to collect and they are required for a secret eighth level and secret ending for 100%. The best part about the gems is they are ALL persistant meaning they remain collected when you die or quit the level. No need having to collect them again! Of course flipping through eversion layers is crucial for going through most levels and collecting gems. There is also a Time Attack mode after the secret ending and you can run through any level in the shortest about of time. It has worldwide leaderboards. I'm working on some good times now. I'm top 40 in the first level, but that's only the first level. Finally, the game has controller support, so grab your Xbox 360 controller if you have one!  THE FINAL LEVEL (SPOILERS!) I'll actually talk about not only the seventh level but the secret eighth level also. The seventh level is one of the few that goes through ALL the layers. You start at a deep layer where the background is red with demonic hands in the background, and no music. Collecting all the gems is tricky work as you have to go back and fourth through the level to find the eversion portals. You don't need to shift to any layer to beat the level, but when you do. You see the ending with the princess becoming a MONSTER. Game over, then the game crashes. So if you want a better ending, you must beat the secret level. At the start of the seventh level, there is a gem count. If you get ALL the gems in the game, you're able to shift to the FINAL layer where it's the DARKEST ever, with enemies regenerating over time. Beating the level with the final layer takes you to the eighth, which is the same deal, except you need to solve puzzles, locate portals, and get to the end to get the good ending. It's similar to the endless castles in SMB. You start at the lowest layer, and work your way up to the top layer to the end of the level. Then the secret ending, it was much more screwed up, as not only has the princess became a monster again, but ZEE TEE as well. WHAT A TWIST.  So that was Eversion. It's a quick game that turns cute to HORRIFYING quick. It can really unsettle you if you're not prepared. Yesterday I started playing this game, beaten the game, got all gems, got the secret ending, and got ALL achievements. It's THAT quick. However it's $5 for a game you could play for free, but you have extra features. I suggest buying it when it's on sale. Like I did! To conclude, Eversion is a fun game with a really interesting gameplay mechanic. I find it have a nice replay value with the graphics and everything. If you're not like me, it's a game to mess around with for a short time until you go tired of it, or a game you can play to waste time on. I recommend this game. Awesome concept.
Another excellent platformer with a unique twist.
what the heck

this game is kind of fun however the reviews and the mysterious nature of this game through the reviews and promo vid are unjustified. not much happens, it's just a basic platformer and the creator couldn't even get that right. the hit boxes are all over the place and you will have your character stood on literally nothing at times. unless it's 50p don't bother
A short game, but very much worth playing. If there is a sequel, I'll make sure to get it.

Eversion is a simple, basic 2D side scrolling platformer. The only twist being that you have the ability to shift environments (eversions). You can shift from six different eversions: deception, erosion, desolation, apprehension, confusion and commotion. Every shift will change colors and backgrounds. The shifts will also turn bushes from leafy, to dead so you can pass through them and into deadly thorn bushes. Some enemies into stone and brick platforms into crumbling blocks. You cannot just shift on a whim, you need to find the invisible area you're supposed to stand in and then shift eversions. When you press the eversion button, if you're close enough to the correct invisible spot, you'll see a ring around it for a brief time. If you're stuck, that usually means you need to backtrack and find the invisible spot.  The gameplay is simple. Like Mario you can destroy bricks by jumping into them and make a gem appear out of blocks by jumping into special ones. Eventually, you will get to see this magical kingdom for what it is. Horrifying, dark and grim. At some point, enemies will spurt bright red blood partially obscuring the screen. Although some might boast this as a horror game, there's nothing really horrific. I was too busy laughing at the giant hands that comically shoot up from death pits. Its too bright and simple of an art style to really be horrific.  There are no power ups. Every hit is instant death, but that's okay because there are no lives. You just respawn at the start of the level or the last checkpoint. The game boasts 8 worlds, but really these worlds are just 8 levels. A world to me feels like it should be more than a level. I was able to breeze through the game in half an hour and that's even looking for invisible eversion points. At the end of each level you hop on a ground flag. There are no bosses, in fact there really only seems to be three enemy types in the game. Monkey claw, goomba and some sort of stone beetle.  Upon completing the game, it just crashed back to the desktop. The only replay value is going back to collect all 240 gems to get better endings that reference better properties. Once you get a gem, it the game considers collected, even if you die on the same run, that gem will not be there. Not having any consequence of death makes things way too easy. This is a quick diversion without any challenge. The forum is full of people giving away 66% off coupons and others talking about how the game is free.

This game is a thoroughly mediocre platformer whose end levels are made incredibly tedious by the seemingly tacked on 'puzzle' elements.  The 'horror' elements that are added to try to make it break out of its meagerness are really about as chilling as a warm, fluffy kitten.  I clicked that I don't recommend the game, but only because, unfortunately, there's no 'eh' option. It's cheap, at least.
Eversion is a fun, creepy, and difficult puzzle platformer. I really like the visual style.
Nintendo hard. I don't care how awesome it's supposed to be, it just makes me punch my leg.
This game is total nightmare fuel and you should take it down! THIS IS TOO SCARY!!!
This game is very........fun.............. (NOT FOR YOUNG CHILDERN THOUGH)
This game will smash your face open with its fist. Also, what a hair style.

Eversion Review  I'll try and fairly state what I can without spoiling too much, although if you simply watch the trailer you already know what's going on here. Eversion is at its core a puzzle platformer, and a clever one too. You control the flower-faced hero named Zee Tee and rescue the princess, so if you've played any NES game before you already know what to do.  Gameplay is basically platforming but with a dimension-warping mechanic where you jump through alternate worlds. You may have to change something in one world in order to affect the other world and then you can get to where you couldn't before. It sounds hard at first but with a bit of practice you will eventually understand what to do. There are collectables throughout the stages to give some replay value, though I wasn't too interested. Things do get shaken up later with different enemies and slightly different ways to play the stage, though generally things remains the same throughout. Of course, the other dimensions might just maybe chinge things up a bit. I will warn you, it will get stressful.  All I can say is don't watch videos of it or look up other reviews because the main thing here which I didn't discuss will be totally spoiled. Simply play Eversion and experience it for yourself.
It's a... it's a game... that's for sure... just, yeah... it's a good game, but, it kind of takes you aback... I feel sorry for the flower thing... its eyes never close...

Eversion is a different sort of game. Despite looking like the bright, cheery platform games of old, this game is a puzzle game with some platform elements. This game features 240 gems, or 'Glitters', scattered around the game's 8 levels. The game boasts the amazing ability to 'evert', or warp between different versions of a level. Each of the worlds use vivid colors, so the game is not overly dark, meaning it could be played well at night. The game boasts a lovely chiptune soundtrack that's best shared alone (why let mere mortals listen to its greatness?). As for playing with friends, Eversion also has a great time attack mode that adds a lot of replay ability. On top of that, there's hidden items to collect in each level, making this a game you'll play a lot, whether you want to or not. Eversion is a wonderfully happy game everyone* should play.  *Not intended for children or those of a nervous disposition.
Nice game, kinda like Mario but with a plot twist.

This game is arguably my favorite game on Steam. Of all the 375 games I own, this is my favorite. The reasons why are nebulous, and cannot be put into words. The way the game progresses is beautiful. This is the epitome of indie pixel art platformers, and you should absolutely spend the $5 to play it.

Quick Breakdown:  A short platformer that centers itself around using what it calls “eversion,” which changes the state of the world.  Length:  30-60 minutes  Genre:  Platformer  Score:  5/10   Full Review:   Eversion  is a fairly simple platformer, you walk left and right, jump across platforms, jump on enemies heads to dispose of them, and collect gems; pretty typical platformer fair. The gimmick for this game is the ability to “evert,” which can only be done at certain points of a level. Everting is activated simply by clicking the key assigned to do so at an evert point. When you evert you change the world around you to an alternate reality. There are 7 different realities in use (plus an 8th hidden one), though most levels only use a small number.  You need to find eversion points to change the world so that you can progress though out the stage, as it will change small things about the world that let you progress. It’s not rocket science figuring out how to use eversion to advance, as it’s all pretty straight forward.  When you begin the game the world starts out very happy and cheery, bright colours and all that. As you descend into the later stages of eversion, the world gradually shifts darker and darker.  The gameplay itself isn’t really anything fancy. In the early levels you’ll notice it draws influence from the original  Super Mario Bros.  This is most notable in the first stage, as it bears a striking resemblance in how the beginning of the level looks.  The gems scattered throughout the game for you to collect don’t serve any purpose, except to unlock a secret level at the end of the game. I didn’t take the time to unlock the secret level, and after pulling it up on youtube to have a look at it, I don’t plan to either, as it doesn’t look like it’s worth the time.  So is it worth buying? Eh, only if you want a short little platformer to kill an hour (if that). There’s a free version available on the developer’s (Zaratustra Productions), though the Steam version features some minor graphical and audio updates. It’s normally $5, though it’s really not worth that price, so I’d wait for it to go on sale. I wish I could give this game a neutral rating, as it’s not good enough to really recommend, nor is it bad enough to advise against purchasing. Take your pick based on if it looks interesting to you or not.
*Quiet whimpering noises*

Looks like a cute little sidescroller, right? Yeah, uhhhm, no. This is a freaky little puzzler disguised as mindless innocent cuteness. You will be weirded out and you will say to yourself, 'holy $#%+!' several times while playing. Definitely one of those indie games worth checking out.
Somehow this is a cool and challanging Jump'n Run game with some kind of rage potential. If you are in to this, so be it. Controlls are a bit weird tho.
It's happy charm at the start will quickly break down as you start peeling away at it's skin only to find a bloody nightmare.

This game looks all innocent and ♥♥♥♥, but I slowly came to the realization that I was merely a pawn in the grand, dark scheme of a Lovecraftian horror. All tangible reality I had once known drifted into the endless eversions. It tortured me, it broke all that I loved, all that I desired and left a single path ahead of me to a certain existence of which no nighmare could ever prepare one for. I say this, grab not ahold of your mind for it will find a way, it will attain all of your deep-seated fears and breathe life into them. Run, run from this heinous and deplorable mind-♥♥♥♥ while you are still able, do not fall for its ostensible innocence!
this is a great game. if you want a great story, easy tradeing cards {6}, or a perfect game. this is a game for you.
Well, that escalated quickly.

This is a very short game (about an hour), with very lackluster graphics. The gameplay itself is great. The 'eversion' mechanic is not the best thing, but it is introduced professionally -- gradually -- and using it to solve puzzles is satisfying, because it doesn't throw the concept in your face; it lets you dwell on it. But again, it is remarkably short: only 7 levels. For a game that uses a concept from the late eighties, it should have more substance/content, but that doesn't negate how fun it still was to play. If it's on sale, and you like childish (as this is a game suitable for a child's entertainment) platformers, I'd recommend it.

This game plays like a typical platformer. There are a few places where it's frustrating because the game requires perfection on the player's part in order to progress. This challenge is offset by the fact that you have unlimited lives, allowing you to practice until perfect. There are multiple endings to strive for. In order to get the 'good' ending, you'll have to collect all 240 gems which requires mastery of the eversion button in order to bypass the obstacles. The graphics range from cute to horrific and the music changes appropriately, providing comlete immersion. I recommend this game as an excellent short-term diversion.

Do not be fooled, this isn't a cute littel kid platformer. It is actually pretty creepy. You start in super happy fun land, but as you pass through certain 'eversion points' you find a dark secret to the land. This was a fun diversion for a couple of hours. There are some clever puzzles using the world shifting mechanics and 3 different endings to find, only 2 of which I think are worth finding. The whole thing took only 2 hours to 100% complete, so it's pretty short. However it was a fun experience that I would reccomend.

A bright beautiful game for all ages! *static* An interesting platformer with engrossing gameplay. *static* A slightly eery and mysterious game with secrets to uncover... *static* A haunting game with surprising that may frighten you....*static* A TERRIFYING GAME THAT WILL STALK YOU IN YOUR NIGHTMARES!! *static* Your children will just love it! In all seriousness, this is a pretty damn good game, but it is very short. I recomend it highly WHEN ON SALE. 7.5/10
A deceptively clever, brilliant and, at times, terrifying platformer. Well worth the asking price.

I haven't beat the game yet, but this may be the most saddest, depressing games ever. Don't think I'm being sarcastic. You might be like 'But the trailer seemed so happy.' Exactly. The soundtrack is haunting and creepy. Imagine Lavender town x1000. It's bad. 10/10
CUTe games DoIng cutE stuff

An old-skool platformer with all the tropes you've come to expect: jump on people, search for hidden secrets, collect stuff ... but with a horror twist. The strangeness that happens is even more creepy with the slight implication that it's you who are causing it, yet you keep going to see if it gets stranger. And just like old-skool games, you can play it straight to rush to the end, or go back and solve some of the puzzles for alternate endings or bragging rights. Highly recommended, and should be played in a dark room.
A very nice indie game, too bad you can finish it in about 2 hours. Still worth buying if you like playing Mario-like games.

If you like platformers, buy this. If you are faint of heart, maybe not. It's cheap, the controls are solid, the play mechanics rock once you figure them out, the twists are entertaining, and the challenges are interesting.   Only thing that I would complain about is that it's a little short - but given the level editor, it isn't hard to extend the experience quite a bit.
I don't want to spoil it, but I can almost guarantee you won't forget your experience playing this game!
This game wasnt all I expected it to be,and thats a good thing! Pretty short, but with some replayability with multiple endings etc. a great value!

A solid platformer with a nice quirky mechanic to keep things interesting, one that gets a bit more layered and complex as you progress further into the game. If you liked platformers back on the NES or SNES, this is right up your alley. It's a little short, but the low price arguably makes that not an issue.
Let's just say you won't forget this game anytime soon.
Small and lovely, with a twist. Few hours of joy, yet the money well worth.

Okay, so unless I haven't done anything wrong, the game is pretty short (took me about 20mins), but the idea behind it is quite creative with the 'layer shiftings'. It starts out cute and happy, but gets darker and more nightmare-like as you go.   The platform style reminds a lot of Super Mario; the overall look of games like Bubble Bobble and co.  You can't turn the sound down, or at least I didn't see an option, but you CAN use a controller, which makes it way nicer to play, IMO.   If anybody is looking for a kind of bizarre, but short, simple; yet interesting little platformer that keeps you busy for a litte or as a thing to set the mood for Halloween even, then go for it.  As the store page says, 8 worlds (aka levels). If you want to make the game last longer, you can (or almost should) also just try to get all the achievements and / or the other 2 alternative endings (there are 3 in total). Cool game. =3

I.. I don't even know. It started out as a cute Mario clone and then there were bombs, and barbed wire, and skeletal hands, and then the eyes. The red eyes. And the princess? I don't know. She was in another castle I guess?  I beat the game. But it's an indie game and I guess I didn't beat it the right way so everything became horrible?   Everyone should probably play this game. So they can explain it to me. And because it is pretty fun.

Behind a thin, candy-coated shell, hides a full-fledged Lovecraftian suprise. As you progress deeper and deeper through the hidden layers of this game, the atmosphere changes from desolation, to desperation, to pure horror! A must-try for Lovecraft fans :)

These devs are insane. They made this game look so sweet and innocent on the store page. IT IS ANYTHING BUT. This game is creepy, freaky, and just plain weird. I enjoy it for its difficulty level of platforming physics. The main menu will make you rip your hair out (same with the settings creen), but once you get past that, the actual gameplay isn't all that bad. The game isn't all that long but that is ok due to its difficulty level. If you want a fun little platformer that will run fine on a netbook or low end laptop, this just might be your game. ~PR0XIDIAN

I have not played a game like this since Super Mario. I bought it just because I saw the similarities (same gameplay), but when I was ingame, it catched me right away. Music is just amazing, for every stage, if you know what I mean by stage. The difficulty is an overall hard. So... the conclusion would be... yes I do recommend this game, it was amazing.
kinda ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ but ok  especially if u r ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. gg
This is not the game I was expecting from the images I had seen. I highly recommend this game. That is all I can say about it, because I don't want to ruin the experience.

'Sounds—possibly musical—heard in the night from other worlds or realms of being.' - H.P. Lovecraft.  Not knowing ahead of time that this cute looking platformer was inspired by Lovecraft, I expected a short, cute game to pass some time. Instead, I freaked out when strange monsters appeared in the sky during the eversions, which is actually the process of turning inside out. It's like the flowers mind was turning inside out into the world outside of him. The game is surprisingly creepy with messages when you die reading, 'Mother.' and 'I Can See You.'  The only levels to remotely appear to be cute are the first two worlds. And then it gets weird. 'The Princess is in another castle.' Or is she? Desolation.  8/10
This game ruinned my life. I thought it was going to be cute flower Mario... but I was so wrong... So wrong...
Super simple platformer, easily beatable in an hour or two.
happy flower
Eversion is difficult to review without giving much away. Let's just say that it is a very colorful game that has some tricks thrown in to keep you guessing. A short but fun game to play!

I decided one day to play a cute platformer game...nothing suspicious at all.  Then I played it properly... and its creepy as hell.   10/10 - would consider the posibilities of eldritch realms of reality masqeurading as other people and the true nature of humanity again.  Thanks Lovecraft.
It's a fun little platformer. More about the atmosphere/story than the gameplay, don't buy it expecting some amazing puzzle platformer.

The game is a platformer offering a moderate challenge, although it is quite short (finished in 40 minutes the first run and three hours for all achievements).   The cute look of the game only tries to hide the real, obscure style of the game  . Quite recommendable for a quick gaming session.
ill see you all in therapy.
This is a fun game with good platforming and an interesting game mechanic. I even got my sister to try it out because of the cute graphics :)
Quite a short game, but a few hours of platformer fun for a few euros. Not bad, but could have more levels or content. Even all of the achievements were easy to get.
